purpose: The code appears to collect system information including MAC addresses, hostname, and user info, then sends this data to external domains via HTTP requests.
anomalies: Use of hardcoded domain names that appear to be part of a tracking or C2 infrastructure
Sending system information to external domains without user consent
Use of 'rejectUnauthorized: false' in HTTP request configuration
Base64 encoding of potentially sensitive system identifiers
analysis: This code collects hardware identifiers (MAC addresses), system metadata (hostname, username), and sends it to multiple external domains that appear to be tracking or command-and-control servers. The use of base64 encoding suggests an attempt at obfuscation. The hardcoded domains and lack of authentication/authorization make this highly suspicious behavior. The 'rejectUnauthorized: false' flag indicates potential man-in-the-middle attack mitigation bypass.
conclusion: This code exhibits clear signs of malicious behavior by collecting system information and exfiltrating it to external tracking domains without explicit user consent, likely for surveillance or data collection purposes.
